Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Advanced Composites in Transportation Vehicles (ACTV)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research of the I/UCRC for Advanced Composites in Transportation Vehicles will span from material development to manufacturing process improvements. Multi-functional nano-composites, natural fiber composites, materials for extreme environments, and out-of-autoclave composites will be investigated while multi-scale material modeling will capture mechanisms at different length and time scales. The durability, damage tolerance, and fracture behavior of composites will be studied. Integrated optimization of material-product systems will be pursued through hierarchically decomposed design optimization methodology. Damage diagnostics and prognostics are intended to enable Condition Based Maintenance for improved safety and reduced life cycle cost.

The proposed I/UCRC has the potential to increase the use of advanced composite structures in aerospace, automotive, and naval vehicles and result in U.S. industrial growth. Advances through center research can lead to reduction of vehicle weight and lower energy consumption compared to current metallic structures and could conceivably alter the current design paradigm for composite materials. Center work is targeted to result in the interdisciplinary and collaborative training of science and engineering students, dissemination of results at technical meetings and in the archival literature, and increased exposure of K-12, community college, and university students to STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF award of Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Advanced Composites in Transportation Vehicles (ACTV) facilitated Mississippi State University (MSU) and The University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH) to organize the Planning Workshop. The Workshop was held at Mississippi State University on July 15-16, 2014. It was attended by prospective industry and government members, faculty and students from the two university partners, Center and Site Directors, NSF Program Directors, and the Center Evaluator. The 60 attendees at the meeting included representatives from 7 private industry, 7 government agencies (excluding NSF), and 1 non-profit organization. Specific objectives of the Workshop were to illustrate I/UCRC concept, governance, and functioning and member influence on project selection and decision making. The objectives also included understanding research needs of the industry, showcase industry-relevant research expertise at the Center sites, and demonstrate benefits of the Center to the community of industry members. The Workshop included presentation of 10 potential research projects by Center faculty, evaluation of the projects by industry/government attendees, decision on Center operation model, and timeline for obtaining letters of commitment from industry/government. Letters of financial commitment from 10 industry/government organizations and one letter of collaboration were received by the end of the Planning Grant period (31 March 2016).
